translated: The Chapter on Hindrances

original: Upajjhāyasutta🔽Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena sako upajjhāyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sakaṁ upajjhāyaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: upajjhāya sutta  atha kho aññataraḥ bhikkhu yena sakaḥ upajjhāyo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā sakam upajjhāyam etat avoca
translated: The Preceptor

original: “etarahi me, bhante, madhurakajāto ceva kāyo, disā ca me na pakkhāyanti, dhammā ca🔽maṁ nappaṭibhanti, thinamiddhañca me cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ
analyzed: etarahi me bhante madhuraka jātaḥ ca iva kāyaḥ disā ca me na pakkhāyanti dhammā ca  mam nappaṭibhanti thinam iddham ca me cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati an abhirataḥ ca brahmacariya
translated: Then a certain monk went to his preceptor and, on arrival, said to him, “At present, my body feels as if it has swallowed poison. The directions aren’t clear to me. The Dhamma

original: carāmi, atthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā”ti.
analyzed: carāmi atthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchāti
translated: doesn’t appear to me. My mind is overcome with sloth & torpor. I’m dissatisfied with the holy life. I have doubts about the teachings.”

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu taṁ saddhivihārikaṁ bhikkhuṁ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami;
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhu tam saddhivihārikam bhikkhum ādāya yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then the monk, taking the student with him, went to the Blessed One and, on arrival, bowed down to him and sat to one side.

original: upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so🔽bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ  bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: and told the Blessed One all that had occurred.

original: “ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu evamāha:
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu evam āha
translated: “Venerable sir, this bhikkhu says this:

original: ‘etarahi me, bhante, madhurakajāto ceva kāyo, disā ca maṁ na pakkhāyanti, dhammā
analyzed: etarahi me bhante madhuraka jātaḥ ca iva kāyaḥ disā ca mamam na pakkhāyanti dhammā
translated: ‘At present my body seems as if it were stuffed with cotton;🔽the directions are not clear to me;🔽my meditation subject is not manifest to me;

original: ca me nappaṭibhanti, thinamiddhañca me cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, anabhirato ca
analyzed: ca me na paṭibhanti thinam iddham ca me cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati an abhirataḥ ca
translated: I am dissatisfied with the spiritual life;

original: brahmacariyaṁ carāmi, atthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā’”ti.🔽“Evañhetaṁ, bhikkhu, hoti indriyesu aguttadvārassa, bhojane amattaññuno, jāgariyaṁ🔽ananuyuttassa, avipassakassa kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ, pubbarattāpararattaṁ bodhipakkhiyānaṁ
analyzed: brahmacariyam carāmi atthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā ati  evam ha ita bhikkhu hoti indriyesu agutta dvārassa bhojane amattaññunaḥ jāgariya  an anuyuttassa a vipassakassa kusalānam dhammāna pubbaratta apararattam bodhi pakkhiyāna
translated: I have doubts about the teachings; I am uncertain, undecided, and unconfident.’“

original: dhammānaṁ bhāvanānuyogaṁ ananuyuttassa viharato, yaṁ madhurakajāto ceva kāyo hoti,
analyzed: dhammānam bhāvanā anuyogam an anuyuttassa viharataḥ yam madhuraka jātaḥ ca iva kāyaḥ hoti
translated: “Bhikkhu, when one is not guarded in the doors of the sense faculties, when one does not know the proper amount in eating, when one is not devoted to wakefulness, when one does not understand wholesome qualities, when one does not associate with a good person, with a wise person, and when one does not attend on a good person, on a wise person, this is the cause and reason why the body seems as if it were stuffed with cotton,

original: disā cassa na pakkhāyanti, dhammā ca taṁ nappaṭibhanti, thinamiddhañcassa cittaṁ
analyzed: disā cassa na pakkhāyanti dhammā ca tam na ppaṭibhanti thinam iddham cassa citta
translated: why the directions are not clear, why the meditation subject is not manifest, why one is dissatisfied with the spiritual life, and why one has doubts about the teachings, is uncertain, undecided, and unconfident.

original: pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ carati, hoti cassa dhammesu vicikicchā.
analyzed: pariyādāya tiṭṭhati an abhirataḥ ca brahmacariyam carati hoti ca assa dhammesu vicikicchā
translated: and he is dissatisfied with the spiritual life.

original: Tasmātiha te, bhikkhu, evaṁ sikkhitabbaṁ:
analyzed: tasmā ati ha te bhikkhu evam
translated: So you should train like this:🔽‘I will be one who guards the doors of the sense faculties,

original: ‘indriyesu guttadvāro bhavissāmi, bhojane mattaññū, jāgariyaṁ anuyutto, vipassako🔽kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ, pubbarattāpararattaṁ bodhipakkhiyānaṁ dhammānaṁ bhāvanānuyogaṁ
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ bhavissāmi bhojane mattaññū jāgariyam anuyuttaḥ vipassakaḥ  kusalānam dhammānam pubbaratta apararattam bodhi pakkhiyānam dhammānam bhāvanā anuyoga
translated: who is moderate in eating, who is devoted to wakefulness,🔽who is an observer of danger in things that can be clung to,

original: anuyutto viharissāmī’ti.
analyzed: anuyuttaḥ viharissāmi iti
translated: and who is intent on developing the meditation that is a property of the Buddhas.’

original: Evañhi te, bhikkhu, sikkhitabban”ti.
analyzed: evam hi te bhikkhu sikkhitabbanti
translated: That’s how you should train.”

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhagavatā iminā ovādena ovadito uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.🔽Atha kho so bhikkhu eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhu bhagavatā iminā ovādena ovaditaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavantam abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā pakkāmi  atha kho so bhikkhu ekaḥ vūpakaṭṭhaḥ appamattaḥ ātāpī pahitattaḥ viharantaḥ nacirassevayassatthāya
translated: Then, having been instructed, inspired, and gladdened by the Buddha, that monk got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

original: kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ
analyzed: kula puttā sammad eva agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajanti tad anuttara brahmacariya pariyosāna
translated: Then, dwelling alone, withdrawn, heedful, ardent, and resolute, he soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual life for which people from good families rightly go forth from home to homelessness.🔽He directly knew: “Destroyed is birth, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming back to any state of being.”

original: diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi
translated: and he entered and remained in the first absorption.

original: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
analyzed: vusitam brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati
translated: He directly knew: “Birth has come to an end, the spiritual life has been fulfilled, the job has been done. There is no further state of existence.”

original: Aññataro pana so bhikkhu arahataṁ ahosi.
analyzed: aññataraḥ pana so bhikkhu arahatam ahosi
translated: And that monk became one of the perfected ones.

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu arahattaṁ patto yena sako upajjhāyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sakaṁ upajjhāyaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhu arahattam pattaḥ yena sakaḥ upajjhāyo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā sakam upajjhāyam etat avoca
translated: Then that monk who had reached perfection went to his preceptor and said,

original: “etarahi me, bhante, na ceva madhurakajāto kāyo, disā ca me pakkhāyanti, dhammā ca
analyzed: etarahi me bhante na ca iva madhuraka jātaḥ kāyaḥ disā ca me pakkhāyanti dhammā ca
translated: “Sir, at present my body doesn’t feel heavy and drugged, and the directions are clear to me.

original: maṁ paṭibhanti, thinamiddhañca me cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, abhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ
analyzed: mam paṭibhanti thinam iddham ca me cittam na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati ca
translated: The Teaching is clear to me, and my mind is not overcome with dullness and drowsiness. I delight in the spiritual life,

original: carāmi, natthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā”ti.
analyzed: carāmi na atthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā ati
translated: and I have no doubt about the teachings.”🔽Then that monk, taking that student with him, went to the Buddha,

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu taṁ saddhivihārikaṁ bhikkhuṁ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami;🔽upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhu tam saddhivihārikam bhikkhum ādāya yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami 🔽upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ
translated: bowed, sat down,

original: bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: and said to the Buddha,

original: “ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu evamāha:
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu evam āha
translated: “Venerable Sir, this monk says,

original: ‘etarahi me, bhante, na ceva madhurakajāto kāyo, disā ca me pakkhāyanti, dhammā ca
analyzed: etarahi me bhante na ca iva madhuraka jātaḥ kāyaḥ disā ca me pakkhāyanti dhammā ca
translated: ‘At present, my body doesn’t feel heavy, the directions are clear to me,

original: maṁ paṭibhanti, thinamiddhañca me cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, abhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ
analyzed: mam paṭibhanti thinam iddham ca me cittam na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati ca
translated: the Teaching is clear to me, my mind is not overcome with dullness and drowsiness,

original: carāmi, natthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā’”ti.
analyzed: carāmi na atthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā ati
translated: I delight in the spiritual life, and I have no doubt about the teachings.’”

original: “Evañhetaṁ, bhikkhu, hoti indriyesu guttadvārassa, bhojane mattaññuno, jāgariyaṁ
analyzed: evam ha ita bhikkhu hoti indriyesu gutta dvārassa bhojane mattaññunaḥ jāgariya
translated: “That’s how it is, monk, when the sense doors are guarded, when one is moderate in eating,🔽when one is devoted to wakefulness,

original: anuyuttassa, vipassakassa kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ, pubbarattāpararattaṁ bodhipakkhiyānaṁ
analyzed: anuyuttassa vipassakassa kusalānam dhammāna pubbaratta apararattam bodhi pakkhiyāna
translated: when one is a seer of skillful qualities, when one is devoted to the practice of the meditation subjects that are skillful qualities,🔽when one is devoted to the practice of the meditation subjects that are skillful qualities in the first and last parts of the night,

original: dhammānaṁ bhāvanānuyogaṁ anuyuttassa viharato, yaṁ na ceva madhurakajāto kāyo hoti,
analyzed: dhammānam bhāvanā anuyogam anuyuttassa viharataḥ yam na ca iva madhuraka jātaḥ kāyaḥ hoti
translated: one’s body doesn’t feel heavy,

original: disā cassa pakkhāyanti, dhammā ca taṁ paṭibhanti, thinamiddhañcassa cittaṁ na pariyādāya
analyzed: disā ca assa pakkhāyanti dhammā ca tam paṭibhanti thinam iddham ca assa cittam na pariyādāya
translated: the directions are clear to one, the Teaching is clear to one, one’s mind is not overcome with dullness and drowsiness,

original: tiṭṭhati, abhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ carati, na cassa hoti dhammesu vicikicchā.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati abhirataḥ ca brahmacariyam carati na cassa hoti dhammesu vicikicchā
translated: and he is pleased with the spiritual life, and he has no perplexity about the teachings.

original: Tasmātiha vo, bhikkhave, evaṁ sikkhitabbaṁ:
analyzed: tasmāt iha vaḥ bhikkhave evam sikkhitabba
translated: Therefore, monks, you should train yourselves thus:

original: ‘indriyesu guttadvārā bhavissāma, bhojane mattaññuno, jāgariyaṁ anuyuttā, vipassakā🔽kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ, pubbarattāpararattaṁ bodhipakkhiyānaṁ dhammānaṁ bhāvanānuyogaṁ
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvārāḥ bhavissāma bhojane mattaññunaḥ jāgariyam anuyuttāḥ vipassakā  kusalānam dhammānam pubbaratta apararattam bodhi pakkhiyānam dhammānam bhāvanā anuyoga
translated: ‘We will guard the doors of our sense faculties, be moderate in eating, and be devoted to wakefulness.

original: anuyuttā viharissāmā’ti.
analyzed: anuyuttāḥ viharissāma ati
translated: We will be endowed with insight into the arising and passing away of phenomena, and we will dwell intent on the development of the seven factors of awakening.’

original: Evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabban”ti.
analyzed: evam hi vaḥ bhikkhave sikkhitabbanti
translated: That’s how you should train.”

original: Chaṭṭhaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 5.57
analyzed: chaṭṭha  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The sixth section on the sense doors is finished.

original: 6. Nīvaraṇavagga
analyzed: nīvaraṇa vagga
translated: The Book of the Sixes🔽The Chapter on Hindrances

original: Abhiṇhapaccavekkhitabbaṭhānasutta
analyzed: abhiṇha paccavekkhitabba ṭhāna sutta
translated: The Bases for Reflection

original: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, ṭhānāni abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbāni itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: pañcimāni bhikkhave ṭhānāni abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbāni itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: “Monks, there are these five bases for reflection that should be frequently reflected upon by a woman or a man, by a householder or one gone forth.

original: Katamāni pañca?
analyzed: katamāni pañca
translated: What five?

original: ‘Jarādhammomhi, jaraṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: jarā dhammaḥ mhi jaram anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: ‘I am subject to old age and I have not gone beyond old age’—this should be frequently reflected upon by a woman or a man, by a householder or one gone forth.

original: ‘Byādhidhammomhi, byādhiṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.🔽‘Maraṇadhammomhi, maraṇaṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: byādhi dhammaḥ mhi byādhim anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā  maraṇa dhammaḥ mhi maraṇam anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: ‘I am subject to illness, not exempt from illness,’ a woman or man, a lay person or one gone forth, should reflect again and again.🔽‘I am subject to death, not exempt from death,’ a woman or man, a lay person or one gone forth, should reflect again and again.

original: ‘Sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvaḥ vinābhāvaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: ‘Separation from those I love is inevitable,’ a woman or man, a lay person or one gone forth, should reflect again and again.

original: ‘Kammassakomhi, kammadāyādo kammayoni kammabandhu kammapaṭisaraṇo.🔽Yaṁ kammaṁ karissāmi—kalyāṇaṁ vā pāpakaṁ vā—
analyzed: kammassakaḥ umhi kamma dāyādaḥ kamma yoni kamma bandhu kamma paṭisaraṇaḥ  yam kammam karissāmi kalyāṇam vā pāpakam vā
translated: ‘I am the owner of my kamma, the heir of my kamma; I have kamma as my origin, kamma as my relative, kamma as my resort;🔽I will be the heir of whatever kamma, good or bad, that I do.’

original: tassa dāyādo bhavissāmī’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: tassa dāyādaḥ bhavissāmi iti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: A woman or man, a lay person or one gone forth, should reflect again and again.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘jarādhammomhi, jaraṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā?
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca jarā dhammaḥ mhi jaram anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: And why, monks, should a woman or a man, a layman or a nun, frequently reflect thus: ‘I am subject to old age and am not exempt from old age’?

original: Atthi, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ yobbane yobbanamado, yena madena mattā kāyena duccaritaṁ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṁ caranti, manasā duccaritaṁ caranti.🔽Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato yo yobbane yobbanamado so sabbaso vā pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave sattānam yobbane yobbana madaḥ yena madena mattā kāyena duccaritam caranti vācāya duccaritam caranti manasā duccaritam caranti  tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ yaḥ yobbane yobbana mado so sabbasas vā pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti
translated: Because, monks, there is intoxication with youth among beings, and for one intoxicated with youth there is no sense of urgency, and without a sense of urgency there is no desire to strive.🔽But for one who frequently reflects thus: ‘I am subject to old age and am not exempt from old age,’ whatever intoxication with youth there may be is abandoned.

original: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘jarādhammomhi, jaraṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: idam kho bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca jarā dhammaḥ mhi jaram anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: This is the reason why a woman or a man, a layman or a nun, should frequently reflect thus: ‘I am subject to old age and am not exempt from old age.’

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘byādhidhammomhi, byādhiṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā?
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca byādhi dhammaḥ mhi byādhim anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: And why, monks, should a woman or a man, a layman or one gone forth, frequently reflect thus: ‘I am subject to illness, not free from illness’?

original: Atthi, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ ārogye ārogyamado, yena madena mattā kāyena duccaritaṁ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṁ caranti, manasā duccaritaṁ caranti.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave sattānam ārogye ārogya madaḥ yena madena mattā kāyena duccaritam caranti vācāya duccaritam caranti manasā duccaritam caranti
translated: Because, monks, there is intoxication with health, and when intoxicated with health one acts in body, speech, and mind in ways that are not in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato yo ārogye ārogyamado so sabbaso vā pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti.
analyzed: tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ yaḥ ārogye ārogya mado so sabbaso vā pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti
translated: For one who frequently reflects upon this, any intoxication with health is abandoned, or at least diminishes.”

original: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘byādhidhammomhi, byādhiṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: idam kho bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca byādhi dhammaḥ mhi byādhim anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: “Monks, this is the reason why a woman or a man, a layman or one gone forth, should frequently reflect thus: ‘I am subject to illness, not free from illness.’

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘maraṇadhammomhi, maraṇaṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā?
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca maraṇa dhammo mhi maraṇam anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: And why, monks, should a woman or a man, a layman or one gone forth, frequently reflect thus: ‘I am subject to death, I am not exempt from death’?

original: Atthi, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ jīvite jīvitamado, yena madena mattā kāyena duccaritaṁ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṁ caranti, manasā duccaritaṁ caranti.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave sattānam jīvite jīvita madaḥ yena madena mattā kāyena duccaritam caranti vācāya duccaritam caranti manasā duccaritam caranti
translated: Because, monks, there is intoxication with life, through which intoxication beings, having gone to the nether world, are seen in an unhappy destination, in a bad destination, in hell.

original: Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato yo jīvite jīvitamado so sabbaso vā pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti.
analyzed: tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ yaḥ jīvite jīvita mado so sabbaso vā pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti
translated: For one who frequently reflects thus, that intoxication with life either disappears altogether or diminishes.

original: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘maraṇadhammomhi, maraṇaṁ anatīto’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: idam kho bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca maraṇa dhammo mhi maraṇam anatītaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: This is the reason why a woman or a man, a layman or one gone forth, should frequently reflect thus: ‘I am subject to death, I am not exempt from death.’

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā?
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvaḥ vinābhāvaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: “And why, monks, should a woman or a man, a layman or a nun, often reflect upon this: ‘Before long we shall be separated and made away from all that is dear and beloved to us’?

original: Atthi, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ piyesu manāpesu yo chandarāgo yena rāgena rattā kāyena duccaritaṁ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṁ caranti, manasā duccaritaṁ caranti.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave sattānam piyesu manāpesu yaḥ chanda rāgaḥ yena rāgena rattāḥ kāyena duccaritam caranti vācāya duccaritam caranti manasā duccaritam caranti
translated: Because, monks, there is a passion and a delight in beings for what is dear and beloved, and because of this passion and delight in beings, they conduct themselves here in body, speech, and mind with passion.

original: Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato yo piyesu manāpesu chandarāgo so sabbaso vā pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti.
analyzed: tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ yaḥ piyesu manāpesu chanda rāgo so sabbaso vā pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti
translated: For one who often reflects upon this, any passion and delight in what is dear and beloved is abandoned or subdued.

original: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: idam kho bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvaḥ vinābhāvaḥ ti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: This is why a woman or a man, a layman or a nun, should often reflect upon this: ‘Before long we shall be separated and made away from all that is dear and beloved to us.’

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘kammassakomhi, kammadāyādo kammayoni kammabandhu kammapaṭisaraṇo, yaṁ kammaṁ karissāmi—
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca kammassakaḥ asmi kamma dāyādaḥ kamma yoni kamma bandhu kamma paṭisaraṇaḥ yam kammam karissāmi
translated: And why, monks, with reference to what, is it said: ‘One is the owner of one’s deeds, heir to one’s deeds, one becomes the heir of deeds done, deeds are the womb from which one is born, deeds are one’s kin, deeds are one’s refuge. Whatever deed one does, whether good or bad, one becomes heir to that deed’?

original: kalyāṇaṁ vā pāpakaṁ vā—tassa dāyādo bhavissāmī’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā?
analyzed: kalyāṇam vā pāpakam vātassa dāyādaḥ bhavissāmi iti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: And why, monks, is it that a woman or a man, a lay person or one gone forth, should often reflect thus: ‘I am the owner of my kamma, the heir of my kamma; I have kamma as my origin, kamma as my relative, kamma as my resort; I will be the heir of whatever kamma, good or bad, that I do’?

original: Atthi, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ kāyaduccaritaṁ vacīduccaritaṁ manoduccaritaṁ.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave sattānam kāya duccaritam vacī duccaritam manaḥ duccarita
translated: Because, monks, there is bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, & mental misconduct.

original: Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato sabbaso vā duccaritaṁ pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti.🔽Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, atthavasaṁ paṭicca ‘kammassakomhi, kammadāyādo kammayoni kammabandhu kammapaṭisaraṇo, yaṁ kammaṁ karissāmi—🔽kalyāṇaṁ vā pāpakaṁ vā—
analyzed: tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhato sabbasas vā duccaritam pahīyati tanu vā pana hoti  idam kho bhikkhave atthavasam paṭicca kammassakaḥ asmi kamma dāyādaḥ kamma yoni kamma bandhu kamma paṭisaraṇaḥ yam kammam karissāmi  kalyāṇam vā pāpakam vā
translated: For one who often reflects thus on that theme, any bodily misconduct is abandoned & its counterpart, good bodily conduct, is undertaken; any verbal misconduct is abandoned & its counterpart, good verbal conduct, is undertaken; any mental misconduct is abandoned & its counterpart, good mental conduct, is undertaken.

original: tassa dāyādo bhavissāmī’ti abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā.
analyzed: tassa dāyādaḥ bhavissāmi iti abhiṇham paccavekkhitabbam itthiyā vā purisena vā gahaṭṭhena vā pabbajitena vā
translated: This is the reason why a woman or a man, a lay person or one gone forth, should often reflect thus: ‘I am the owner of my kamma, the heir of my kamma; I have kamma as my origin, kamma as my relative, kamma as my resort; I will be the heir of whatever kamma, good or bad, that I do.’

original: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: sa kho saḥ bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: He considers this and comes to the conclusion:

original: ‘na kho ahaññeveko jarādhammo jaraṁ anatīto, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṁ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbe sattā jarādhammā jaraṁ anatītā’ti.
analyzed: na kho ahaññā eva ekaḥ jarā dhammo jaram anatītaḥ atha kho yāvatā sattānam āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbe sattā jarā dhammā jaram anatītā ati
translated: ‘I am not the only one who is subject to old age and cannot escape it. As long as there are beings subject to birth, all of them are subject to old age.’

original: Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato maggo sañjāyati.
analyzed: tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ maggo sañjāyati
translated: As he frequently reflects on this, the path is generated in him.

original: So taṁ maggaṁ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: saḥ tam maggam āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti
translated: He develops it, repeatedly practicing it.

original: Tassa taṁ maggaṁ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṁyojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti anusayā byantīhonti.
analyzed: tassa tam maggam āsevataḥ bhāvayataḥ bahulīkarotaḥ sayojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti anusayāḥ byantīhonti
translated: As he does so, all his fetters are completely abandoned and his inherent tendencies are brought to an end.

original: ‘Na kho ahaññeveko byādhidhammo byādhiṁ anatīto, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṁ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbe sattā byādhidhammā byādhiṁ anatītā’ti.🔽Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato maggo sañjāyati.
analyzed: na kho ahaññā eva ekaḥ byādhi dhammaḥ byādhim anatītaḥ atha kho yāvatā sattānam āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbe sattā byādhi dhammā byādhim anatītā ati  tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ maggo sañjāyati
translated: ‘I am not the only one who is subject to illness and cannot escape it. As long as there are beings subject to birth, all of them are subject to illness.’🔽As he frequently reflects on this, the path is generated in him.

original: So taṁ maggaṁ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: saḥ tam maggam āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti
translated: He develops it, repeatedly practicing it.

original: Tassa taṁ maggaṁ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṁyojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti, anusayā byantīhonti.
analyzed: tassa tam maggam āsevataḥ bhāvayataḥ bahulīkarotaḥ sayojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti anusayāḥ byantīhonti
translated: As he does so, all his fetters are abandoned and his inherent tendencies are brought to an end.

original: ‘Na kho ahaññeveko maraṇadhammo maraṇaṁ anatīto, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṁ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbe sattā maraṇadhammā maraṇaṁ anatītā’ti.🔽Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato maggo sañjāyati.
analyzed: na kho ahaññā eva ekaḥ maraṇa dhammo maraṇam anatītaḥ atha kho yāvatā sattānam āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbe sattā maraṇa dhammā maraṇam anatītā ati  tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ maggo sañjāyati
translated: ‘Not only I am subject to death, not exempt from death, but for as long as there are beings, coming and going, passing away and being reborn in accordance with the law of kamma, all beings are subject to death, not exempt from death.’🔽As he frequently reflects upon this, the path is generated in him.

original: So taṁ maggaṁ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: saḥ tam maggam āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti
translated: He cultivates, develops, and repeats that path.

original: Tassa taṁ maggaṁ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṁyojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti, anusayā byantīhonti.
analyzed: tassa tam maggam āsevataḥ bhāvayataḥ bahulīkarotaḥ sayojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti anusayāḥ byantīhonti
translated: As he does so, all his fetters are abandoned and his inherent tendencies are brought to an end.

original: ‘Na kho mayhevekassa sabbehi piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṁ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṁ sattānaṁ piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo’ti.
analyzed: na kho mayhā iva ekassa sabbehi piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvaḥ vinābhāvaḥ atha kho yāvatā sattānam āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesam sattānam piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvaḥ vinābhāvaḥ ti
translated: ‘Not only I am subject to separation from all that is pleasing and dear, to being deprived of it, but for as long as there are beings, coming and going, passing away and being reborn in accordance with the law of kamma, all beings are subject to separation from all that is pleasing and dear, to being deprived of it.’

original: Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato maggo sañjāyati.
analyzed: tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ maggo sañjāyati
translated: As he frequently reflects upon this, the path is generated in him.

original: So taṁ maggaṁ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: saḥ tam maggam āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti
translated: He cultivates that path, develops it, and makes much of it.

original: Tassa taṁ maggaṁ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṁyojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti, anusayā byantīhonti.
analyzed: tassa tam maggam āsevataḥ bhāvayataḥ bahulīkarotaḥ sayojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti anusayāḥ byantīhonti
translated: As he does so, all his fetters are abandoned, and his underlying tendencies are uprooted.🔽‘I am not the only one who is the owner of one’s kamma, the heir of one’s kamma;🔽who has kamma as one’s origin, kamma as one’s relative, kamma as one’s resort;

original: ‘Na kho ahaññeveko kammassako kammadāyādo kammayoni kammabandhu kammapaṭisaraṇo, yaṁ kammaṁ karissāmi—kalyāṇaṁ vā pāpakaṁ vā—tassa dāyādo bhavissāmi;
analyzed: na kho aham neva ekaḥ kammassakaḥ kamma dāyādaḥ kamma yoni kamma bandhu kamma paṭisaraṇaḥ yam kammam karissāmi kalyāṇam vā pāpakam vā atassa dāyādaḥ bhavissāmi
translated: who will be the heir of whatever kamma, good or bad, that I do.

original: atha kho yāvatā sattānaṁ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbe sattā kammassakā kammadāyādā🔽kammayoni kammabandhu kammapaṭisaraṇā, yaṁ kammaṁ karissanti—kalyāṇaṁ vā pāpakaṁ
analyzed: atha kho yāvatā sattānam āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbe sattā kammassakā kamma dāyādā  kamma yoni kamma bandhu kamma paṭisaraṇāḥ yam kammam karissanti kalyāṇam vā pāpaka
translated: All beings are the owners of their kamma, the heirs of their kamma;🔽they have kamma as their origin, kamma as their relative, kamma as their resort;

original: vā—tassa dāyādā bhavissantī’ti.🔽Tassa taṁ ṭhānaṁ abhiṇhaṁ paccavekkhato maggo sañjāyati.
analyzed: vātassa dāyādāḥ bhavissanti iti  tassa tam ṭhānam abhiṇham paccavekkhataḥ maggo sañjāyati
translated: they will be the heirs of whatever kamma, good or bad, that they do.’🔽As he frequently gives careful attention to this, the path is generated in him.

original: So taṁ maggaṁ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
analyzed: saḥ tam maggam āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti
translated: He cultivates that path, develops it, and makes much of it.

original: Tassa taṁ maggaṁ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṁyojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti, anusayā byantīhontīti.
analyzed: tassa tam maggam āsevataḥ bhāvayataḥ bahulīkarotaḥ sayojanāni sabbaso pahīyanti anusayāḥ byantīhonti iti
translated: As he does so, all his fetters are abandoned, and his underlying tendencies are uprooted.”

original: Byādhidhammā jarādhammā,
analyzed: byādhi dhammā jarā dhammā
translated: They are subject to sickness, subject to old age,

original: atho maraṇadhammino;
analyzed: atho maraṇa dhammino
translated: and subject to death.

original: Yathā dhammā tathā sattā,
analyzed: yathā dhammā tathā sattā
translated: Beings are just like these phenomena.

original: jigucchanti puthujjanā.🔽Ahañce taṁ jiguccheyyaṁ,
analyzed: jigucchanti puthujjanā  aham ced tam jiguccheyya
translated: Ordinary people are disgusted.🔽If I were to be disgusted

analyzed: evam dhammesu pāṇisu

analyzed: jīvitasmin ca ye madāḥ

analyzed: nekkhammam daṭṭhu khemataḥ

analyzed: nibbānam abhipassataḥ

analyzed: kāmāni paṭisevitu

analyzed: licchavi kumāraka sutta

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā vesāliyaṁ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṁ.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā vesāliyam viharati mahā vane kūṭāgāra sālāya
translated: One day the Blessed One was staying near Vesālī in the Great Wood in the hall with the peaked roof.

original: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya vesālim piṇḍāya pāvisi
translated: Then, in the morning, the Blessed One dressed, took his bowl and robe, and entered Vesālī for alms.

original: Vesāliyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto mahāvanaṁ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: vesāliyam piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ mahā vanam ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmim rukkha mūle divāvihāram nisīdi
translated: After his meal, on his return from his alms round, he entered the Great Wood, and sat down at the root of a certain tree for the day’s abiding.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā licchavikumārakā sajjāni dhanūni ādāya kukkurasaṅghaparivutā🔽mahāvane anucaṅkamamānā anuvicaramānā addasu bhagavantaṁ aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle nisinnaṁ;
analyzed: tena khalu pana samayena sambahulā licchavi kumārakā sajjāni dhanūni ādāya kukkura saṅgha parivutā  mahā vane anucaṅkamamānāḥ anuvicaramānāḥ addasu bhagavantam aññatarasmim rukkha mūle nisinna
translated: Now at that time a number of Licchavī youths, having taken bows and arrows, were practicing archery in the Great Wood.🔽They saw the Lord sitting at the root of a certain tree,

original: disvāna sajjāni dhanūni nikkhipitvā kukkurasaṅghaṁ ekamantaṁ uyyojetvā yena bhagavā
analyzed: disvāna sajjāni dhanūni nikkhipitvā kukkura saṅgham ekamantam uyyojetvā yena bhagavā
translated: and having seen him, they put down their bows and arrows, sent away the troop of dogs,

original: tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā tuṇhībhūtā tuṇhībhūtā pañjalikā
analyzed: tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā tuṇhībhūtā tuṇhībhūtā pañjalikā
translated: and approached the Lord; having approached, having greeted the Lord, they stood in front of him keeping silence, keeping silence with hands raised in respectful salutation

original: bhagavantaṁ payirupāsanti.
analyzed: bhagavantam payiḥ upāsanti
translated: and were paying homage to the Lord.

original: Tena kho pana samayena mahānāmo licchavi mahāvane jaṅghāvihāraṁ anucaṅkamamāno addasa te licchavikumārake tuṇhībhūte tuṇhībhūte pañjalike bhagavantaṁ payirupāsante;
analyzed: tena khalu pana samayena mahānāmaḥ licchavi mahā vane jaṅghāvihāram anucaṅkamamānaḥ addasa te licchavi kumārake tuṇhībhūte tuṇhībhūte pañjalike bhagavantam payis upāsante
translated: Now at that time Mahānāma the Licchavī, while walking and wandering for exercise, saw those Licchavī youths standing in front of the Lord keeping silence, keeping silence with hands raised in respectful salutation🔽and paying homage to the Lord,

original: disvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.🔽Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho mahānāmo licchavi udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: disvā yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi  ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho mahānāmaḥ licchavi udānam udānesi
translated: and approached the Buddha. He bowed down to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

original: “bhavissanti vajjī, bhavissanti vajjī”ti.🔽“Kiṁ pana tvaṁ, mahānāma, evaṁ vadesi:
analyzed: bhavissanti vajjī bhavissanti vajjī iti  kim pana tva mahā nāma evam vadesi
translated: As he was sitting there, Mahānāma exclaimed, “The Vajjis are lost! The Vajjis are lost!”

original: ‘ciraṁ jīva, dīghamāyuṁ pālehī’ti.
analyzed: ciram jīva dīgham āyum pālehi iti
translated: ‘May the master live long; may he not die soon; may he live for a long time.’

translated: When a clansman is helped by the king’s justice, he can expect growth, not decline.

original: Tamenaṁ balipaṭiggāhikā devatā sakkatā garukatā mānitā pūjitā kalyāṇena manasā anukampanti:
analyzed: tam enam bali paṭiggāhikāḥ devatā sakkatā garukatā mānitā pūjitā kalyāṇena manasā anukampanti
translated: “Again, a clansman gains wealth by energetic, diligent, & persistent effort. He gains wealth by the strength of his arms, through his own efforts; what he gains he gains lawfully. He makes himself happy & satisfied—happy & satisfied, he makes his mother & father happy & satisfied; happy & satisfied, he makes his wife & children, his slaves, workers, & servants happy & satisfied; happy & satisfied, he makes his friends & companions happy & satisfied.🔽He makes offerings to renunciants & brahmans, thinking, ‘May this offering of mine be of great fruit & benefit.’🔽When he makes offerings to renunciants & brahmans, thinking, ‘May this offering of mine be of great fruit & benefit,’ the renunciants & brahmans, being rightly-gone, rightly-detailed, rightly-instructed, teach him the Dhamma.🔽The renunciants & brahmans, being rightly-gone, rightly-detailed, rightly-instructed, teach him the Dhamma.

original: ‘ciraṁ jīva, dīghamāyuṁ pālehī’ti.

translated: “Bhikkhus, it is by developing and cultivating these five things that a bhikkhu who has destroyed the taints declares final knowledge thus:

translated: ‘I understand: Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.’

translated: “If he wishes: ‘May I wield the various kinds of supernormal power: having been one, may I become many; having been many, may I become one; may I appear and vanish; may I go unhindered through a wall, through a rampart, through a mountain as though through space; may I dive in and out of the earth as though through water; may I walk on water without sinking as though it were dry land; seated cross-legged, may I travel in space like a bird; with my hand may I touch and stroke the moon and sun so powerful and mighty; may I exercise mastery with the body as far as the brahma world,’

original: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṁ pāpuṇiṁ sati sati āyatane.
analyzed: tatra tatra iva sakkhibhabbatam pāpuṇim sati sati āyatane
translated: then, because of the destruction of the five lower fetters, he is due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana, without ever returning from that world.

original: So sace ākaṅkhiṁ …pe… ‘āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,

translated: “If he wishes: ‘May I, with the destruction of the five lower fetters, become an attainer of Nibbana in the interval,’

original: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṁ pāpuṇiṁ sati sati āyatane”ti.
analyzed: tatra tatra iva sakkhibhabbatam pāpuṇim sati sati āyatane iti
translated: and I attained the ability to be a witness,🔽here and now, of those very things.

original: Aṭṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: aṭṭhama
translated: I attained the ability to be a witness, through direct knowledge, of anything that can be known by direct knowledge, in each and every case.”🔽The eighth section on the wilderness is finished.

translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu dwells contemplating the unattractiveness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving non-delight in the entire world, contemplating impermanence in all conditioned things, and keeping in being the perception of death.

analyzed: saḥ tehi dhamma vitakkehi divasam atināmeti riñcati na anuyuñjati ajjhattam

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhu bhikkhu vitakka bahulaḥ no dhamma vihārī
translated: This bhikkhu is called one who is abundant in reflection, not in abiding in the Dhamma.

original: Idha, bhikkhu, bhikkhu dhammaṁ pariyāpuṇāti—
analyzed: idha bhikkhu bhikkhu dhammam pariyāpuṇāti
translated: “Here, bhikkhu, a bhikkhu learns the Dhamma—

translated: He does not go beyond the proper time in listening to the Dhamma, nor does he neglect seclusion. He practices meditation internally, with regard to the mind.

translated: Bhikkhu, whatever should be done by a teacher out of compassion and goodwill for his disciples who are free from lust, but are still stained by some slight imperfection, has been done by me for you.

original: Etāni, bhikkhu, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyatha, bhikkhu, mā pamādattha, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṁ vo amhākaṁ anusāsanī”ti.

translated: Here, bhikkhu, are the roots of trees, here are empty huts. Meditate, bhikkhu, do not delay or else you will regret it later. This is our instruction to you.”🔽This is the third time I have given you this simile, thinking: ‘May the venerable Maha Kaccana be pleased.’🔽Pleased, the venerable Maha Kaccana was satisfied with what the venerable Ananda said.

translated: “Again, a bhikkhu can endure a cloud of dust,

original: api ca kho dhajaggaññeva disvā saṁsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ.
analyzed: api ca kho dhajaggaññā iva disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu
translated: but when he sees a banner he becomes frightened, agitated, and terrified, and is unable to continue in the holy life.

original: Sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: He reveals his weakness in training, gives up the training, and reverts to the lower life.

original: Kimassa dhajaggasmiṁ?
analyzed: kimassa dhajaggasmi
translated: What is a banner for him?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva kho suṇāti:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu na ha iva kho suṇāti
translated: Here a bhikkhu does not hear:

original: ‘amukasmiṁ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā’ti;
analyzed: amukasmin nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgatā ati
translated: ‘In such and such a village or town a woman or a man is beautiful, pleasant, attractive, of noble race and good breeding, endowed with the most excellent complexion, possessing perfect beauty and grace.’

original: api ca kho sāmaṁ passati itthiṁ vā kumāriṁ vā abhirūpaṁ dassanīyaṁ pāsādikaṁ paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgataṁ.
analyzed: api ca kho sāmam passati itthim vā kumārim vā abhirūpam dassanīyam pāsādikam paramāya vaṇṇa pokkhara tāya samannāgata
translated: But he sees a woman or a girl who is well-developed, with a fine figure and shapely limbs, and who is attractive, lovely, and charming.

original: So taṁ disvā saṁsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ.
analyzed: saḥ tam disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu
translated: When he sees her, he lusts after her. He loses his persistence, becomes slack, and is unable to maintain an ascetic life.

original: Sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: He reveals his weakness in training, gives up the training, and reverts to the lower life.

original: Idamassa dhajaggasmiṁ.🔽Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ;
analyzed: idamassa dhajaggasmi  seyyathā api saḥ bhikkhave yodha ājīvaḥ sahati
translated: This is his flag.

original: api ca kho dhajaggaññeva disvā saṁsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti saṅgāmaṁ otarituṁ;🔽tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ puggalaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: api ca kho dhajaggaññā iva disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmam otaritu  tathūpamā āha bhikkhave imam puggalam vadāmi
translated: “Just as that warrior is one who can endure the cloud of dust but not the top of the standard,

original: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api bhikkhave idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: so too is this person.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, dutiyo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: bhikkhave dutiyaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalo santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the second kind of person similar to a warrior found among the bhikkhus.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṁ, sahati dhajaggaṁ;
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sahati rajagga sahati dhajagga
translated: “Again, some bhikkhu can endure the cloud of dust and the top of the standard,

original: api ca kho ussāraṇaññeva sutvā saṁsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ.
analyzed: api ca kho ussāraṇaññā iva sutvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu
translated: but on hearing the shout, he sinks, founders, does not brace himself, and cannot maintain the spiritual life.

original: Sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: He reveals his weakness in the training, gives up the training, and reverts to the lower life.

original: Kimassa ussāraṇāya?
analyzed: kim assa ussāraṇāya
translated: What is the shout for him?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṁ araññagataṁ vā rukkhamūlagataṁ vā suññāgāragataṁ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā ūhasati ullapati ujjagghati uppaṇḍeti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhum arañña gatam vā rukkha mūla gatam vā suññāgāra gatam vā mātugāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā ūhasati ullapati ujjagghati uppaṇḍeti
translated: It’s when a woman approaches a monk who has gone to the wilderness, to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and she teases, torments, and persecutes him.

original: So mātugāmena ūhasiyamāno ullapiyamāno ujjagghiyamāno uppaṇḍiyamāno saṁsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ.
analyzed: saḥ mātugāmena ūhasiyamānaḥ ullapiyamānaḥ ujjagghiyamānaḥ uppaṇḍiyamānaḥ sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu
translated: And the monk, being teased, tormented, and persecuted by the woman, sinks, founders, does not brace himself, and cannot maintain the spiritual life.

original: Sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: He reveals his weakness in the training, gives up the training, and reverts to the lower life.

original: Idamassa ussāraṇāya.
analyzed: idam assa ussāraṇāya
translated: This is the shout for him.

original: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ, sahati dhajaggaṁ;
analyzed: seyyathā api saḥ bhikkhave yodha ājīvaḥ sahati rajagga sahati dhajagga
translated: It’s like a warrior who can endure a cloud of dust and a flutter of flags,

original: api ca kho ussāraṇaññeva sutvā saṁsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti saṅgāmaṁ otarituṁ;🔽tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ puggalaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: api ca kho ussāraṇaññā iva sutvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmam otaritu  tathūpamā āha bhikkhave imam puggalam vadāmi
translated: but on hearing the shout, he sinks down, founders, does not brace himself, and cannot enter the battle;🔽so too is this person similar to the warrior who runs away in battle and is the last to flee.

original: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api bhikkhave idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: There is, bhikkhus, such a person here.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, tatiyo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.🔽Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṁ, sahati dhajaggaṁ, sahati ussāraṇaṁ;
analyzed: bhikkhave tatiyaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalo santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu  puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sahati rajagga sahati dhajagga sahati ussāraṇa
translated: This is the third kind of person similar to a warrior found among the bhikkhus.

original: api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati.
analyzed: api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati
translated: “Again, some bhikkhu can endure the dust and the banner, but he is struck down and finished off by the shout.

original: Kimassa sampahārasmiṁ?
analyzed: kim assa sampahārasmi
translated: What is the shout by which he is struck down and finished off?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṁ araññagataṁ vā rukkhamūlagataṁ vā suññāgāragataṁ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhum arañña gatam vā rukkha mūla gatam vā suññāgāra gatam vā mātugāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati
translated: Here, when a bhikkhu has gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty hut, a woman approaches him, sits down or lies down next to him, and embraces him.

original: So mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamāno abhinipajjiyamāno ajjhotthariyamāno sikkhaṁ apaccakkhāya dubbalyaṁ anāvikatvā methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevati.
analyzed: saḥ mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamānaḥ abhinipajjiyamānaḥ ajjhotthariyamānaḥ sikkham a paccakkhāya dubbalyam an āvikatvā methunam dhammam paṭisevati
translated: The bhikkhu consents to this and does not draw back. He does not inform the bhikkhus, but keeps silent.

original: Idamassa sampahārasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam assa sampahārasmi
translated: This is his defeat.

original: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ, sahati dhajaggaṁ, sahati ussāraṇaṁ, api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati;🔽tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ puggalaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: seyyathā api saḥ bhikkhave yodha ājīvaḥ sahati rajagga sahati dhajagga sahati ussāraṇa api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati  tathūpamā āha bhikkhave imam puggalam vadāmi
translated: “Just as that warrior is able to endure the cloud of dust, the banner, and the shout, but is slain and wounded by the clash of arms, so too is this person.🔽This is the kind of person who is comparable to a warrior who is able to endure the cloud of dust, the banner, and the shout, but is slain and wounded by the clash of arms.

original: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api bhikkhave idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: There is, bhikkhus, such a person here.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, catuttho yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: bhikkhave catutthaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalo santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the fourth kind of person similar to a warrior found among the bhikkhus.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṁ, sahati dhajaggaṁ, sahati ussāraṇaṁ,
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu sahati rajagga sahati dhajagga sahati ussāraṇa
translated: “Again, some bhikkhu is able to endure the cloud of dust, the banner, and the shout,

original: sahati sampahāraṁ, so taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṁ ajjhāvasati.
analyzed: sahati sampahāra saḥ tam saṅgāmam abhivijinitvā vijita saṅgāmaḥ tam eva saṅgāma sīsam ajjhāvasati
translated: and the clash of arms. Having triumphed in that battle, he emerges victorious and settles at the head of the battlefield.

original: Kimassa saṅgāmavijayasmiṁ?
analyzed: kim assa saṅgām avijayasmi
translated: What is his victory in battle?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṁ araññagataṁ vā rukkhamūlagataṁ vā suññāgāragataṁ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhum arañña gatam vā rukkha mūla gatam vā suññāgāra gatam vā mātugāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati
translated: Here, when a bhikkhu has gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty hut, a woman approaches him, sits down or lies down next to him, and embraces him.

original: So mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamāno abhinipajjiyamāno ajjhotthariyamāno viniveṭhetvā vinimocetvā yena kāmaṁ pakkamati.🔽So vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamānaḥ abhinipajjiyamānaḥ ajjhotthariyamānaḥ viniveṭhetvā vinimocetvā yena kāmam pakkamati  so vivittam senāsanam bhajati araññam rukkha mūlam pabbatam kandaram giri guham su sānam vana pattham abbhokāsam palāla puñja
translated: When he is being sat on, lain with, and rubbed against by women, he turns away, turns aside, and departs.🔽He frequents a solitary lodging, a forest, the foot of a tree, a mountain, a ravine, a hillside cave, a charnel ground, a jungle thicket, an open space, a heap of straw.

original: So araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: saḥ arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: When he has gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down, folding his legs crosswise, straightening his body, and establishing mindfulness in front of him.

original: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: saḥ abhijjham loke pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittam parisodheti
translated: Having abandoned longing for the world, he dwells with a mind free from longing; he purifies his mind from longing.

original: byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: byāpāda padosam pahāya a byāpanna cittaḥ viharati sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī byāpāda padosā cittam parisodheti
translated: Having abandoned ill will and hatred, he dwells with a mind free from ill will, compassionate toward all living beings; he purifies his mind from ill will and hatred.

original: thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: thinamiddham pahāya vigata thinamiddhaḥ viharati āloka saññī sataḥ sampajānaḥ thinamiddhā cittam parisodheti
translated: Having abandoned dullness and drowsiness, he dwells free from dullness and drowsiness, percipient of light, mindful and clearly comprehending; he purifies his mind from dullness and drowsiness.

original: uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccam pahāya anuddhataḥ viharati ajjhattam vūpasanta cittaḥ uddhacca kukkuccā cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up restlessness and anxiety, and dwells without mental agitation, with a mind inwardly peaceful, and he purifies his mind of restlessness and anxiety.

original: vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: vicikiccham pahāya tiṇṇa vicikicchaḥ viharati a kathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu vicikicchāya cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up doubt, and dwells having gone beyond doubt, without uncertainty as to what things are wholesome, and he purifies his mind of doubt.

original: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
analyzed: saḥ ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
translated: He abandons these five hindrances, which are defilements of the mind and weaken wisdom,

original: vivicceva kāmehi …pe…🔽catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi pe  catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: and, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states,🔽he enters and dwells in the first jhāna, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by directed thought and evaluation.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.🔽So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,🔽‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti  saḥ idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti  ayam dukkha nirodho ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati
translated: When his concentrated mind is purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.🔽He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’;🔽he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘These are the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the taints’;🔽he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: ime āsavāḥ ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘These are the taints.’ He understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the taints.’

original: ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti🔽yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: ayam āsava nirodha uti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati  yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the taints.’ He understands as it really is:🔽‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati,
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Idamassa saṅgāmavijayasmiṁ.🔽Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ, sahati dhajaggaṁ, sahati ussāraṇaṁ,
analyzed: idam assa saṅgām avijayasmi  seyyathā api saḥ bhikkhave yodha ājīvaḥ sahati rajagga sahati dhajagga sahati ussāraṇa
translated: This is his victory in battle.🔽“Just as that warrior is called a victor in battle who conquers his enemies in battle and remains undefeated himself, and who can thus dwell in the midst of the battlefield,

original: sahati sampahāraṁ, so taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṁ ajjhāvasati;🔽tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ puggalaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: sahati sampahāra saḥ tam saṅgāmam abhivijinitvā vijita saṅgāmaḥ tam eva saṅgāma sīsam ajjhāvasati 🔽tathūpamā āha bhikkhave imam puggalam vadāmi
translated: so too is this person called one who conquers in the midst of battle.

original: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api bhikkhave idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: Such a person exists among the monks.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, pañcamo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: bhikkhave pañcamaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalo santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the fifth type of person similar to a warrior found among the monks.

original: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca yodhājīvūpamā puggalā santo saṁvijjamānā bhikkhūsū”ti.🔽Pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave pañca yodha ājīva upamā puggalā santaḥ savijjamānā bhikkhūsu iti  pañcama
translated: These are the five types of persons similar to warriors found among the monks.”🔽The fifth section for recitation on the person similar to a warrior is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 5.76

translated: He frequents a secluded lodging, a forest, the foot of a tree, a mountain, a ravine, a hillside cave, a charnel ground, a jungle thicket, an open space, a heap of straw.

original: So araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: saḥ arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: When he has gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down, folding his legs crosswise, straightening his body, and establishing mindfulness in front of him.

original: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya …pe… so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
analyzed: saḥ abhijjham loke pahāya pe saḥ ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
translated: Having abandoned longing for the world …

original: vivicceva kāmehi …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi pe catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: he dwells having attained the fourth absorption.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.🔽So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe…
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti  saḥ idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam pajānāti pe
translated: When his mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he extends it toward knowledge of the destruction of the taints.🔽He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering.’ …

original: nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāti.
analyzed: na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: ‘This is the origin of suffering.’ …🔽‘This is the cessation of suffering.’ …🔽‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ …

original: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo asicammaṁ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṁ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṁ
analyzed: seyyathā api saḥ bhikkhave yodha ājīvaḥ asi cammam gahetvā dhanu kalāpam sannayhitvā viyūḍha
translated: Just as a warrior who takes up a sword and shield, arms himself with a bow and arrows,

original: saṅgāmaṁ otarati, so taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṁ
analyzed: saṅgāmam otarati saḥ tam saṅgāmam abhivijinitvā vijita saṅgāmaḥ tam eva
translated: and enters the battle, and having triumphed in that battle,

original: ajjhāvasati; tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ puggalaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: ajjhāvasati tathūpamā āha bhikkhave imam puggalam vadāmi
translated: lives by conquering in battle, so too is this person, I say.

original: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api bhikkhave idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: Such a person is to be found here.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, pañcamo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: bhikkhave pañcamaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalo santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the fifth kind of person similar to a warrior found among the bhikkhus.

original: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca yodhājīvūpamā puggalā santo saṁvijjamānā bhikkhūsū”ti.
analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave pañca yodha ājīva upamā puggalā santaḥ savijjamānā bhikkhūsu iti
translated: These are the five kinds of persons similar to warriors found among the bhikkhus.”

original: Chaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: chaṭṭha
translated: The sixth section on those similar to warriors is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 5.77
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Fives

original: 8. Yodhājīvavagga
analyzed: yodha ājīva vagga
translated: The Group on Warriors

original: Paṭhamaanāgatabhayasutta🔽“Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, anāgatabhayāni sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā
analyzed: paṭhama anāgata bhaya sutta  pañcimāni bhikkhave anāgata bhayāni sampassamānena alam eva āraññikena bhikkhunā
translated: 1. The First Fearful Things

original: appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṁ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
analyzed: appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharitum appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
translated: “Bhikkhus, when a forest bhikkhu sees five fearful things, it is enough for him to dwell heedful, ardent, and resolute out of desire for the supreme security from bondage.🔽He should reflect thus:

original: asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya
translated: to realize what has not been realized.

original: Katamāni pañca?
analyzed: katamāni pañca
translated: What are the five?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave āraññikaḥ bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a forest bhikkhu reflects thus:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho etarahi ekako araññe viharāmi.
analyzed: aham kho etarahi ekakaḥ araññe viharāmi
translated: ‘At present I am living alone in the forest.

original: Ekakaṁ kho pana maṁ araññe viharantaṁ
analyzed: ekakam kho pana mama araññe viharanta
translated: But when I am living alone in the forest,

original: ahi vā maṁ ḍaṁseyya, vicchiko vā maṁ ḍaṁseyya, satapadī vā maṁ ḍaṁseyya,
analyzed: ahi vā mam ḍaseyya vicchikaḥ vā mam ḍaseyya satapadī vā mam ḍaseyya
translated: a snake might bite me, a scorpion might sting me, or a centipede might sting me.

original: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā, so mamassa antarāyo;
analyzed: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā saḥ mamassa antarāyaḥ
translated: That would be a hindrance for me.

original: handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.🔽Idaṁ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṁ anāgatabhayaṁ sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā🔽appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṁ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
analyzed: handa aham vīriyam ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā an adhigatassa adhigamāya a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya ati  bhikkhave paṭhamam anāgata bhayam sampassamānena alam eva āraññikena bhikkhunā  appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharitum appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
translated: Let me now arouse energy for the attainment of the as-yet-unattained, for the achievement of the as-yet-unachieved, for the realization of the as-yet-unrealized.’

original: asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya
translated: Seeing this danger in the future, it is enough for a forest bhikkhu to dwell heedful, ardent, and resolute for the attainment of the as-yet-unattained, for the achievement of the as-yet-unachieved, for the realization of the as-yet-unrealized.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave āraññikaḥ bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: Again, an animal might kill me in the forest.

original: ‘ahaṁ kho etarahi ekako araññe viharāmi.🔽Ekako kho panāhaṁ araññe viharanto
analyzed: aham kho etarahi ekakaḥ araññe viharāmi  ekakaḥ kho pana aham araññe viharantaḥ
translated: ‘At present I’m living alone in the wilderness.🔽But if I were to fall down or get sick,

original: upakkhalitvā vā papateyyaṁ, bhattaṁ vā bhuttaṁ me byāpajjeyya, pittaṁ vā me kuppeyya, semhaṁ vā me kuppeyya, satthakā vā me vātā kuppeyyuṁ,
analyzed: upakkhalitvā vā papateyya bhattam vā bhuttam me byāpajjeyya pittam vā me kuppeyya semham vā me kuppeyya satthakāḥ vā me vātāḥ kuppeyyu
translated: or if my food were to disagree with me, or if bile, phlegm, or piercing winds were to arise in me,

original: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā, so mamassa antarāyo;
analyzed: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā saḥ mamassa antarāyaḥ
translated: that would be an obstacle for me.

original: handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.🔽Idaṁ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṁ anāgatabhayaṁ sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā🔽appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṁ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
analyzed: handa aham vīriyam ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā an adhigatassa adhigamāya a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya ati  idam bhikkhave dutiyam anāgata bhayam sampassamānena alam eva āraññikena bhikkhunā  appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharitum appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
translated: Let me now make an effort for the attainment of the as-yet-unattained, for the achievement of the as-yet-unachieved, for the realization of the as-yet-unrealized.’

original: asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya
translated: This is the second future peril considering which it’s enough for a wilderness-dwelling monk to dwell heedful, ardent, & resolute for the attainment of the as-yet-unattained, for the achievement of the as-yet-unachieved, for the realization of the as-yet-unrealized.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave āraññikaḥ bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “And further, a wilderness-dwelling monk considers thus:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho etarahi ekako araññe viharāmi.
analyzed: aham kho etarahi ekakaḥ araññe viharāmi
translated: ‘At present I’m living alone in the wilderness.

original: Ekako kho panāhaṁ araññe viharanto
analyzed: ekakaḥ kho pana aham araññe viharantaḥ
translated: While living alone in the wilderness,

original: vāḷehi samāgaccheyyaṁ, sīhena vā byagghena vā dīpinā vā acchena vā taracchena vā, te maṁ jīvitā voropeyyuṁ,
analyzed: vāḷehi samāgaccheyya sīhena vā byagghena vā dīpinā vā acchena vā taracchena vā te mama jīvitā voropeyyu
translated: I might meet with wild spirits, lions, tigers, leopards, bears, and hyenas, and they might take my life.

original: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā, so mamassa antarāyo;
analyzed: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā saḥ mamassa antarāyaḥ
translated: That would be a hindrance for me.

analyzed: handa aham vīriyam ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā an adhigatassa adhigamāya a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya ati  idam bhikkhave tatiyam anāgata bhayam sampassamānena alam eva āraññikena bhikkhunā  appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharitum appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
translated: Let me now arouse energy for the attainment of the as-yet-unattained, for the achievement of the as-yet-unachieved, for the realization of the as-yet-unrealized.’

original: asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya
translated: This is the third future peril considering which it is enough for a wilderness-dwelling monk to dwell heedful, ardent, and resolute for the attainment of the as-yet-unattained, for the achievement of the as-yet-unachieved, for the realization of the as-yet-unrealized.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave āraññikaḥ bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Again, a wilderness-dwelling monk considers thus:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho etarahi ekako araññe viharāmi.
analyzed: aham kho etarahi ekakaḥ araññe viharāmi
translated: ‘At present I am living alone in the wilderness.

original: Ekako kho panāhaṁ araññe viharanto
analyzed: ekakaḥ kho pana aham araññe viharantaḥ
translated: While living alone in the wilderness,

original: māṇavehi samāgaccheyyaṁ katakammehi vā akatakammehi vā, te maṁ jīvitā voropeyyuṁ,
analyzed: māṇavehi samāgaccheyyam kata kammehi vā a kata kammehi vā te mama jīvitā voropeyyu
translated: I might meet with young men, whether they’ve finished their work or not, and they might deprive me of life.

analyzed: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā saḥ mamassa antarāyaḥ
translated: That would be a hindrance for me.

analyzed: handa aham vīriyam ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā an adhigatassa adhigamāya a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya ati  bhikkhave catuttham anāgata bhayam sampassamānena alam eva āraññikena bhikkhunā
translated: Let me now arouse energy for the attainment of the as-yet-unattained, for the achievement of the as-yet-unachieved, for the realization of the as-yet-unrealized.’

original: appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṁ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya🔽asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharitum appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya  a sacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya
translated: This is the fourth future peril considering which it is enough for a wilderness-dwelling monk to dwell heedful, ardent, and resolute… for the realization of the as-yet-unrealized.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave āraññikaḥ bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Again, the wilderness-dwelling monk considers thus:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho etarahi ekako araññe viharāmi.
analyzed: aham kho etarahi ekakaḥ araññe viharāmi
translated: ‘At present I am dwelling alone in the wilderness.

original: Santi kho panāraññe vāḷā amanussā, te maṁ jīvitā voropeyyuṁ,
analyzed: santi kho pana araññe vāḷāḥ amanussā te mama jīvitā voropeyyu
translated: But there are wild beasts in the wilderness—lions, tigers, panthers, bears, and hyenas—that might deprive me of life.
